captions.text: You told Walcott l cheated.

l know you did it.
Just tell me why.
Look, cut the crap, Hunter.

l live with you. l know how much
you study, or don't study.

And you do better than me ?
Give me a break.

You arrogant, pompous prick !
Who appointed you custodian
of the medical profession ?

ls it because your father
and his father was a doctor,
some sort of genetic thing ?

- You're damn right.
- Really ?
l grew up with it.

l know what it takes to look in the eyes
of dying people day after day...

and come home
for dinner at night.

- l know what it takes.
You don't have it.
- Oh, really. And you do ?

lf you don't like me,
just say it.
l don't like you !

Why don't you like me ?
You're a prick, and l like you.

Because you make
my effort a joke !

l want to be a doctor !
This isn't a game to me !
This isn't playtime !
This is serious business !

l have it in me
to be a great doctor...

but in order to do that l have to
sacrifice if l want to be better.

''Better.''
Better than me, hmm ?

[ Sighs ] l will save lives that
could have otherwise not been saved.

Now, l could be like you and go around
Iaughing and have a good time, ha ha,

but l prefer to learn,
because the more l learn,

the more likely l will
have the right answer at the
crucial moment and save a life.

And you say l'm a prick ?
You say l'm a prick ?
You know, maybe l am,

but you ask the average person, when
death comes knocking at their door...

whether they want a prick on their side
or some kindergarten teacher...
who's gonna kiss their ass !

Because when that day comes
l want the prick...
and so will you.

You know, l forget
how young you are, Mitch...

that you think you have to be a prick
to get things done...

and that you actually think
that that's a new idea.
[ Sighs ]
[ Pen Falls To Desk ]

title: Patch Adams (6/10) Movie CLIP - To Be a Great Doctor (1998) HD

comments.text:
Strange that both of these actors died before their time. I wonder, was it 
fate, does fate exist, perhaps yes, just baffling watching two dead people 
at their best. ﻿
comments.author: fmnma1

comments.text:
And both actors murdered themselves! Someone should have locked them both 
up in an institution so a real doctor could have saved them!﻿
comments.author: Jason Smith

comments.text:
The sad thing about their deaths despite both their immense talents they 
had personal demons which sadly caught up to them. But from what we knew of 
both Robin and Philip is that they truly were cinematic icons and beloved 
figures in the history of film. I'll certainly remember Robin Williams for 
how much joy he brought to a cross generation of film goers and Philip 
Seymour Hoffman for his intensity and psychological transformation for 
certain roles he was given. The film industry just doesn't feel the same 
anymore now that they are no longer with us, but their legacies will live 
on.﻿
comments.author: Max Kennedy

comments.text:
Both of these men are acting gods and this is a crucial scene. Their sudden 
departures in this past year have made it a very dark period in the movie 
industry for sure. But we should celebrate their incredible bodies of work 
and honour their memories, not focus in on the final moments of their 
lives, as traumatic as they were. I'm sure it's not what they'd want. 
Seymour Hoffman and Williams busted their asses nearly everyday of the year 
without hesitation to entertain millions of people worldwide.﻿

Id rather have patch. He knew how to treat people and would also treat

comments.author: ratso69ful

comments.text:
A lot has been said and remembered about Robin Williams since his passing 
on Monday. Through all the best moments lists and clip compilations, 
though, I haven't seen this fantastic bit from Patch Adams mentioned.

It's an otherwise forgettable movie, but this scene between Williams and 
Philip Seymour Hoffman (also lost way too early) almost makes it okay. I 
found Williams' final line to be particularly powerful, and — apart from 
the entirety of Dead Poets Society — it's probably the moment in his career 
that seared me the most.

"I forget how young you are… you think you have to be a prick to get things 
done. And you actually think that that's a new idea."

Dead on. RIP, Robin.﻿

Both of these actors were taken from us too soon. On a side note, this 
scene seems to have the unintentional effect of making us side with

comments.text:
That's what's so wonderful about the ambiguity of this scene. We side with 
him because there is no one, single, correct philosophy here.
comments.author: Kujakuseki01

comments.text:
I still think he had stronger points overall, his problem was that he 
needed to brush up on his bedside manner. In the end, I would prefer the 
professionalism that Hoffman brings instead of Williams but I do see the 
importance in lifting up the spirits of those who are terminally ill.
comments.author: Auroby

comments.text:
It's a powerful scene because both guys are right --- doctors do have to 
take things serious because death is all around ---- but Williams has a 
point because humor and compassion can be the only medicine left for a 
dying patient
comments.author: Tom Miller

comments.text:
Good point. But I think the truth of what both said made them realize that 
life is complicated. Hoffman's character made a valid point. But Williams 
forced him to realize that in fact what he was saying was not new. Watch 
Hoffman's reaction after Williams leaves. He is pensive and the truth of 
what Williams said was making him re-think his passion to be a "prick".

comments.author: Ben Ashcraft

comments.text:
I hope you aren't insinuating that God wasn't there for these two gentlemen 
as their lives went spiraling out of control. No, God was there. God is 
always there, here, because he loves us. We have been allowed a knowledge 
of right and wrong, and He gives us a choice. God doesn't make wrong 
choices, man does....Why do atheists always blame God for things He gives 
us control over?

I pray Williams and Hoffman have received their salvation through God's 
good grace. Whatever they did to themselves, I believe they left a very 
positive impression within God's creation. None of us are perfect. Let us 
not blame the one who is perfect.
comments.author: 1q2w3e4r911

comments.text:
I didn't think both of these guys would go the same year of 2014. Robin 
Williams in Mrs.Doubtfire was my favorite for him. Philip Seymour Hoffman 
in Along Came Polly was my favorite for him. Ben Stiller knew both of these 
actors in those movies. Amazing that Robin in this movie takes humor to 
ease hospital policy depression and Philip takes medical policy seriously 
and on the contrary in the normal lives of these actors, they did the 
opposite. Robin kills himself for not being happy and Philip kills himself 
by abusing drugs. That make sense? I would think these actors would learn 
something from their characters, but I could be wrong and simply was an 
accident. Robin was my favorite and hero, because he had Asperger's 
syndrome.﻿

People think drugs are the problem, but they're really only a symptom of 
the problem. I believe Hoffman was depressed, and saw drugs as his escape. 
He may not have wanted to die, but I don't see how succumbing to your 
addiction could be seen as wanting to live. It's not like he didn't know 
what he was getting himself into. He just decided not to save himself the 
way he had done earlier in his life.

comments.author: ef28

comments.text:
The issues of this film is that it isn't accurate at all.  Robin's 
performance made Patch too much of a clown.  The real Patch was serious in 
becoming a doctor and incorporated joy and laughter into his practice. He 
did not steal from the hospital, and his murdered friend was not female 
(Monica Potter).  And Philip makes a good point: if you had to choose 
between a prick or a clown, you would choose the one who acts more 
professional.  The movie still has a great message but they could have 
portrayed it more accurately.﻿
comments.author: Andrew Miller
